results.content:
Content / code sample are good; not the usual beginner stuff. The explanations are very vague and the walk through of the code pretty painful. The explanations were not that great compared to other udemy instructors. 

However, even with lack of detailed explanations and responses to questions, the advanced nature of the course gets 3 stars for its difficulty level and exposure to many different technologies.

results.content:
If anyone wants to quickly catch up Spring Boot Application with Angular JS (especially this is a niche market to learn on and online has limited resources), you should follow his course.

I recognize Le Deng is a very good developer, and the way he teaches us through phase to phase to develop a project is extremely useful and this is what really happening in a real market. 

You know when you just joined a new company, and Spring Boot application is a new language you must learn yourself, you can learn this course, because he won't teach you so deeply what java entity, what does it mean, what is spring boot...., but he will teach you the approach to think, how to use Eclipse to implement.

Even I learn only 14% complete now, I must say thank you so much to Le Deng. For those who rated his course lower, I may recommend you should learn other beginner courses, because his course is for real developer,tbh!
results.content_html:

First of all, this is NOT a course for beginners, if you're not familiar with some of these technologies, better watch other courses.
I think that this course is good, because working on this Bank Project makes me satisfied and many technologies are being touched on. Materials shown in films are rather up-to-date. About disadvantages, codes in films are copy-paste and keyboard sounds are too loud. I think sometimes (because of copy-paste code) author doesn't explain everything enough and clear. Despite these disadvantages money on this course are well-spended and the time i've spent on this project was a good investment.

results.content:
Hello Everyone,

This is a fantastic course to get your self acquainted with range of different technologies like - Spring Thymeleaf, Security, Data, REST, Hibernate, Angular 2 & Angular CLI. 

I have not been coding for few years and I was looking for something that will help me to brush up some comprehensive set of technologies. This course was perfect to achieve my goal. The best part is that the author has developed the entire project from scratch so by the end of the course, you get an entire overview as to how all these technologies will gel together for an enterprise project.

I also think it is essential for people to be familiar with at least one MVC, ORM, Security and Client side framework before taking this course. Also make sure that you code while going through videos. It does not matter even if you copy paste the source code but make sure that you understand each and every line written by author.

Thank you very much !!
results.content_html:
Hello Everyone,

This is a fantastic course to get your self acquainted with range of different technologies like - Spring Thymeleaf, Security, Data, REST, Hibernate, Angular 2 & Angular CLI.

I have not been coding for few years and I was looking for something that will help me to brush up some comprehensive set of technologies. This course was perfect to achieve my goal. The best part is that the author has developed the entire project from scratch so by the end of the course, you get an entire overview as to how all these technologies will gel together for an enterprise project.

I also think it is essential for people to be familiar with at least one MVC, ORM, Security and Client side framework before taking this course. Also make sure that you code while going through videos. It does not matter even if you copy paste the source code but make sure that you understand each and every line written by author.

Thank you very much !!

results.content: This course goes straight to the point when it proposes you to build an app using the mentioned technologies. Good as a refresher and also for getting some important points for the first timers. Maybe some updated lessons could be added to show differences between Angular 2 and Angular 8 and eventually some new feature of the Spring Framework. Other point it could be improved is how to deploy this solution on https production server or add tests.
results.content_html: This course goes straight to the point when it proposes you to build an app using the mentioned technologies. Good as a refresher and also for getting some important points for the first timers. Maybe some updated lessons could be added to show differences between Angular 2 and Angular 8 and eventually some new feature of the Spring Framework. Other point it could be improved is how to deploy this solution on https production server or add tests.

results.content:
It was an awesome course! I can see how much preparation and effort Deng put into it.

I also like the fact that he used a lot of technologies that are useful in the real world and can help you get a job, but there are a couple of things I'd like to point out.

I understand that in order to save some time, Deng just copy-pasted the code and then explained it, but I think if he would've typed the code by hand, he'd go into more details.

The number one thing that would've improve this course, is if we wouldn't write code in advance. There were couple of times where we used classes and functions which did not exist yet. I think this could be fixed by taking my first suggestion, and not copying code, but writing them by hand.

I would've liked a bit more detailed explanation of a few things (like the thymeleaf and spring security bit) but since this course isn't for beginners I think that its ok.

All in all its a greate course, does what it says in the preview video! :)
results.content_html:
It was an awesome course! I can see how much preparation and effort Deng put into it.

I also like the fact that he used a lot of technologies that are useful in the real world and can help you get a job, but there are a couple of things I'd like to point out.

I understand that in order to save some time, Deng just copy-pasted the code and then explained it, but I think if he would've typed the code by hand, he'd go into more details.

The number one thing that would've improve this course, is if we wouldn't write code in advance. There were couple of times where we used classes and functions which did not exist yet. I think this could be fixed by taking my first suggestion, and not copying code, but writing them by hand.

I would've liked a bit more detailed explanation of a few things (like the thymeleaf and spring security bit) but since this course isn't for beginners I think that its ok.

All in all its a greate course, does what it says in the preview video! :)

results.content: The course doesn't start from scratch. It's based on a continuous copy/paste from an already created project. I would also disagree on some design decisions (like not using inheritance on Accounts) and would like more explanations on how thymeleaf or jQuery is used. Some tasks like adding pom dependencies are solved by a copy/paste solution without further explanation (why not search for them in search.maven.org and access the dependency code there?). Anyway, the code could be a useful piece of reference.
results.content_html: The course doesn't start from scratch. It's based on a continuous copy/paste from an already created project. I would also disagree on some design decisions (like not using inheritance on Accounts) and would like more explanations on how thymeleaf or jQuery is used. Some tasks like adding pom dependencies are solved by a copy/paste solution without further explanation (why not search for them in search.maven.org and access the dependency code there?). Anyway, the code could be a useful piece of reference.

results.content: The author did a good job by setting the backend and frontend pieces together. The course is dedicated for beginners, but most of the topics have a high-level explanation without much of details. I assume that will be tough for beginners. Some parts of the course such as deployment are not finished, deprecated methods not updated and Angular 2 is outdated.  In the end you'll get a high-level understanding of the backend/fronend technologies that will hopefully help you in taking a decision what to learn next.
results.content_html: The author did a good job by setting the backend and frontend pieces together. The course is dedicated for beginners, but most of the topics have a high-level explanation without much of details. I assume that will be tough for beginners. Some parts of the course such as deployment are not finished, deprecated methods not updated and Angular 2 is outdated. In the end you'll get a high-level understanding of the backend/fronend technologies that will hopefully help you in taking a decision what to learn next.

results.content: The course was good in general, but I was not satisfied at some chapters. I was stacked at some points for a little time due to poor explanation. I also found some error in cycling of dependencies or no validations of forms. I also find writing the implementation class at first and then defining methods in interface not the appropriate way - no Override annotations are there and, it need to be written two times, too. I suggest using power of IDE and generate as much code as possible. Also, more explanation of some specific Spring parts would be great. It was too many features implemented in this course, but I think it was described weakly and also it could be done more precisely, with validations e.g. It would be nice to have explanation of how the Spring is handling such problems, not only read the pasted code. To sum up, this course provides very nice example of how to create web application using Spring, but there is also space to improve.
results.content_html: The course was good in general, but I was not satisfied at some chapters. I was stacked at some points for a little time due to poor explanation. I also found some error in cycling of dependencies or no validations of forms. I also find writing the implementation class at first and then defining methods in interface not the appropriate way - no Override annotations are there and, it need to be written two times, too. I suggest using power of IDE and generate as much code as possible. Also, more explanation of some specific Spring parts would be great. It was too many features implemented in this course, but I think it was described weakly and also it could be done more precisely, with validations e.g. It would be nice to have explanation of how the Spring is handling such problems, not only read the pasted code. To sum up, this course provides very nice example of how to create web application using Spring, but there is also space to improve.

results.content:
Alright so first off, there are a lot of good things about this course. First I've learned about CrudRepository and Hibernate being able to automatically fill in a database with tables.

The main issue is the way Le Deng presents his code. It's such bad practice to copy and paste your code and then explain what you just copied and pasted. It would be 100% better to retype the code and explain as you're typing or as you have typed it and pause to explain it.
results.content_html:
Alright so first off, there are a lot of good things about this course. First I've learned about CrudRepository and Hibernate being able to automatically fill in a database with tables.

The main issue is the way Le Deng presents his code. It's such bad practice to copy and paste your code and then explain what you just copied and pasted. It would be 100% better to retype the code and explain as you're typing or as you have typed it and pause to explain it.

results.content: I agree. You'd need some prior knowledge (this is why it is suggested that the video is paused and required research done prior to continuing), however, this is one of the few courses that actually gives an entire overview of how a complete system is built end-to-end, and in less than 7 hours. Well done Le Deng!

results.content:
When I bought this course, I read the review where people were saying that he just copy paste the code, dont explain etc. Still I decided to buy the course because he mentioned in course description that this course is not teaching you basic concepts. I thought I will learn by myself by looking at his code and it will help me to create complete portal.

After few sessions , I am stuck at the page where login in the app doesnt work. I copied exact code which he is using in my code still dont work. I am still not complaining that why it is not working but he is not supporting at all. I posted questions but he dont reply. Even I saw in the Q&A many other have the same problem and they also posted the question but there is no response from him. I at least Expect him to respond to help us to solve the problem. I think he dont care about this at all.

Until and unless you are expert in Spring Boot, Spring Security then and then by this course. But If you are expert then why would you even buy the course :) I am stuck currently

results.content:
I think highly... However there some issues with the accent which may be an issue to non native speakers (basically people for whom English is a secondary language acquired later in life and don't get much practice). 
Also I admit I'm split on one hand the course has great quality content but, it skips a few steps and requires strong familiarity with everything in it. I am an Android developer with some web development experience and have to look some things up. Still it's worth as the material is of high quality instead of being short hello world apps

results.content: Very Practical Course with the latest code especially for Spring and Hibernate. Thymeleaf does a great job at making the frontend function more easily than JSF. Looking forward to get more hands on courses like this.
results.content_html: Very Practical Course with the latest code especially for Spring and Hibernate. Thymeleaf does a great job at making the frontend function more easily than JSF. Looking forward to get more hands on courses like this.

results.content:
While it's a little slow at the beginning, we're getting a very good overview of how to approach why and how to build an application. That is incredibly important and seemingly unique with MOOCs!
UPDATE: I've finished most the course and it was incredibly beneficial. I got to learn a lot of backend and frontend technologies and how they worked together. I've actually purchased more courses by this instructor as a result. It has helped me at school and my internship.
